text: Hanjin's board unanimously agreed to make the court filing at a meeting on Wednesday, a company spokesman said. It faces a cash shortage after failing to persuade key lenders to reschedule debt under a new restructuring plan. Shares of Hanjin remain suspended in Seoul after plunging by as much as 29% on Tuesday. Hanjin, which is also the world's seventh-largest container line, has been unprofitable for four of the last five years. Hanjin may get some financial relief courtesy of rival Hyundai Merchant Marine (HMM). Shares of HMM jumped by as much as 22% after Korea's financial regulator said the firm may buy some of Hanjin's assets. However HMM hasn't been spared from the woes bedevilling the sector. It recently announced a reorganisation plan too. South Korea's shipping and shipbuilding industry is one of the hardest-hit by a prolonged downturn in global trade. A drop in orders has led to overcapacity and depressed freight rates, as well as an increase in debts. "Korean shipping companies have suffered large losses largely because charter rates on leased vessels were fixed in 2010 at a high level while actual shipping rates have fallen," Nomura analyst Young Sun Kwon said. The South Korean government is now looking to undertake a painful reorganisation of the entire industry, which will require major retrenchments. The ongoing restructuring is one of several reasons why we expect growth to be weak this year and next, Krystal Tan from Capital Economics said. "The loss of tens of thousands of jobs certainly won't help economic sentiment," she added. "But it is a relatively small number when set against the 26m people in employment in Korea so we're not likely to see a big spike in the unemployment rate."

text: Hanjin 's board unanimously agreed to make the court filing at a meeting on Wednesday , a company spokesman said . It faces a cash shortage after failing to persuade key lenders to reschedule debt under a new restructuring plan . Shares of Hanjin remain suspended in Seoul after plunging by as much as 29 % on Tuesday . Hanjin , which is also the world seventh-largest container shipping line, said it has filed for court receivership after its banks withdrew support. The South Korean company's move, following Korea Development Bank's (KDB) decision to halt financial aid, deals a severe blow to global trade, potentially leaving billions of dollars worth of goods stranded. This could become the largest container shipping bankruptcy, disrupting supply chains globally before the peak shopping season. Already, U.S. and Chinese ports refuse Hanjin ships entry, and some vessels have been seized by creditors. The South Korean government has voiced deep concern, urging domestic rivals like Hyundai Merchant Marine (HMM) to consider taking over some of Hanjin's routes, vessels, and personnel. Financial regulators in Seoul are coordinating efforts to mitigate economic fallout. Hyundai Merchant Marine (HMM), itself recently restructured, has expressed readiness to cooperate with government plans to stabilize the market. This might involve acquiring Hanjins healthy assets, such as port terminals or select ships, to ensure service continuity. Details are pending court proceedings in Seoul. Creditors, led by KDB, found Hanjin's self-rescue proposals insufficient by the September 4 deadline, leading to negotiation collapse. This signals Hanjin Shipping's likely end, prompting significant reshuffling in global shipping alliances as other major carriers absorb its market share. The incident highlights severe challenges facing the broader shipping sector, long struggling with overcapacity and weak demand. Focus is now on the Seoul court's actions and swift asset transfer to operators like Hyundai Merchant Marine (HMM) to limit widespread disruption.
label: T2

text: South Korea's biggest shipping group Hanjin is set to enter receivership after its creditors refused to provide further funding to the indebted firm.

text: Hanjin's board unanimously voted on Wednesday to file for court protection, a company spokesman confirmed. This decision follows the company's failure to convince key lenders to reschedule its debt under a new restructuring plan, leading to a severe cash shortage. Hanjin's shares remain suspended in Seoul, having plummeted by as much as 29% on Tuesday. The world's seventh-largest container line, Hanjin has reported unprofitability in four of the last five years. Some financial reprieve for Hanjin may come from rival Hyundai Merchant Marine (HMM). HMM's shares surged by up to 22% after Korea's financial regulator indicated that the firm might acquire some of Hanjin's assets. Nevertheless, HMM has not been unaffected by the difficulties plaguing the sector, having recently announced its own reorganization strategy. South Korea's shipping and shipbuilding industries are among those most severely impacted by a prolonged global trade downturn. A decline in orders has resulted in overcapacity, suppressed freight rates, and an escalation of debts. Nomura analyst Young Sun Kwon explained that Korean shipping companies have suffered substantial losses primarily because charter rates for leased vessels were fixed at high levels in 2010, while actual shipping rates have subsequently fallen. The South Korean government is now preparing to implement a difficult, industry-wide restructuring, which will necessitate significant job cuts. Krystal Tan from Capital Economics stated that this ongoing restructuring is one reason why weak economic growth is anticipated this year and next. She added that the loss of tens of thousands of jobs would certainly negatively affect economic sentiment. However, she believes this number is relatively small when compared to the 26 million people employed in Korea, meaning a large increase in the unemployment rate is unlikely.

text: Chief Inspector of Prisons Peter Clarke published his findings following unannounced inspections. Challenges included staff shortages and increased use of new psychoactive substances, leading to more "unpredictable and violent behaviour". But inspectors also found good staff-prisoner relationships and a "good range" of training and education. Despite safety declining since 2013, Mr Clarke described it as a "mixed picture of progress". There were 770 inmates at the time of the inspections in July and August, despite the Certified Normal Accommodation (CNA) level - how many prisoners can be held safely and decently - being 532. Other positives in the report included an improvement in resettling prisoners after release, but it found some cells were in a poor state and there was a lack of bedding. The report said: "Despite these challenges, it did not feel unstable and staff-prisoner relationships had been maintained." Head of the National Offender Management Service, Michael Spurr, said: "Despite significant operational pressures the prison has continued to deliver a positive regime with good levels of purposeful activity and effective support of prisoners before release." But campaign group, the Howard League for Penal Reform, described it as an "overcrowded and understaffed prison where it is easy to get drugs but much harder to get clean bedding". The recently-introduced smoking ban was described as "unpopular with some". Frances Crook, chief executive of the Howard League, said: "This inspection report on Cardiff prison is slightly better than reports on other prisons which we have seen of late, but still it raises considerable cause for concern." Responding to the report, Cardiff Central MP Jo Stevens said: "This report makes clear that there are huge areas of concern for Cardiff prison and these can be added to the long list of wake up calls to the Prisons Minister. "Urgent action by the government is needed."
label: T1

text: Chief Inspector of Prisons Peter Clarke published his findings following unannounced inspections . Challenges included staff shortages and increased use of new psychoactive substances , leading to more " unpredictable and violent behaviour " . But inspectors also found good staff - prisoner relationships and a " good range " of training and education . Despite safety declining since 2013 , Mr Clarke described it as a " mixed picture of progress throughout the prison estate. While some institutions demonstrated resilience and effective leadership, Peter Clarke's report highlighted a persistent struggle with systemic issues that continued to undermine the safe and effective operation of many establishments across England and Wales. The surge in violence, often linked directly to the ready availability of illicit drugs like spice, placed immense strain on both resources and the morale of dedicated staff. A significant challenge identified by Clarke was the ongoing problem of staff retention. This issue, exacerbated by the demanding and often dangerous work environment, meant that many prisons struggled to deliver a full daily regime, leading to extended periods of lock-up for prisoners. Such reduced out-of-cell time often fueled frustration and further escalated tensions within already volatile environments. Crucially, the report by Clarke also drew attention to the critical issue of prison capacity. Many establishments were operating significantly above their certified normal accommodation. This widespread overcrowding, where cells designed for a single inmate were frequently housing two or even three, directly contributed to the documented decline in safety and the notable increase in violent incidents. It severely limited personal space, heightened friction between inmates, and made effective supervision considerably more difficult for staff. Peter Clarke underscored the urgent need for sustained investment, not just in the physical infrastructure of prisons, but vitally in the recruitment, retention, and well-being of frontline staff. He emphasized that prioritizing the mental and physical health of both prisoners and staff was essential for creating environments truly conducive to rehabilitation, rather than merely containment. The Chief Inspector warned that without tackling these deep-seated structural issues, including the fundamental mismatch between the rising prison population and the available certified normal accommodation, the risk of further deterioration in safety and order within the nation's prisons remained unacceptably high. His findings provided a sobering assessment, urging the government to adopt a comprehensive and strategic approach to adequately resource and manage the future integrity of the entire prison system.
label: T2

text: Cardiff prison needs to tackle its drug problem but is stable despite "challenging times", a report has said.
label: T3

text: Peter Clarke, the Chief Inspector of Prisons, released his findings following unannounced inspections. Key issues identified were insufficient staffing and a rise in the use of new psychoactive substances, which contributed to more erratic and aggressive conduct. However, inspectors also observed positive interactions between staff and prisoners, alongside a diverse array of training and educational opportunities. Although safety levels had worsened since 2013, Mr. Clarke characterized the situation as a complex blend of advancements and setbacks. During the July and August inspections, the prison held 770 inmates, significantly exceeding its Certified Normal Accommodation (CNA) capacity of 532, which indicates the number of prisoners that can be safely and humanely housed. Additional positive aspects noted in the report included better progress in rehabilitating inmates post-release. Conversely, some cells were in disrepair, and there was insufficient bedding. The report indicated that despite difficulties, the facility didn't feel unstable, and good staff-prisoner relations persisted. Michael Spurr, head of the National Offender Management Service, stated that even with considerable operational demands, the prison has maintained a constructive system offering ample purposeful activities and effective pre-release support for inmates. In contrast, the Howard League for Penal Reform, a campaign group, depicted it as an "overcrowded and understaffed facility where drug access is easy, but clean bedding is scarce." The recently implemented smoking prohibition was noted as being "unpopular among certain individuals." Frances Crook, the Howard League's chief executive, commented that while "this inspection report for Cardiff prison is marginally better than other recent prison reports we've reviewed, it still presents significant reasons for concern." Cardiff Central MP Jo Stevens, in her response, asserted that "this report plainly highlights major areas of concern for Cardiff prison, adding to the numerous warnings the Prisons Minister has received. The government must take urgent action."
label: T4

text: The Citroen driver from Dungannon won three out of the four stages in the Tour de Course. Ogier stayed within touching distance of the Meeke, who is aiming to follow up his dramatic victory in Rally Mexico with another win. Huyundai's Thierry Neuville holds third, 25.8 seconds off the lead. Meeke took control early on the first Asphalt round of the season, winning the opening stage before adding two more stage wins before the end of the day . Four-time world champion Ogier was fastest in SS3 in his M-Sport Ford to cut Meeke's advantage to just over eight seconds, however he responded on the final stage to extend his advantage over 10 seconds. "It's been a good day," said Meeke, 37. "You always have to be wary of Seb, because he never gives up. But I'm comfortable with my pace, so let's see how we go on Saturday." Meeke's Citroen team-mate Craig Breen holds an impressive fourth, with the Waterford driver locked in a tight battle with Spaniard Dani Sordo.
label: T1

text: The Citroen driver from Dungannon won three out of the four stages in the Tour de Course . Ogier stayed within touching distance of the Meeke , who is aiming to follow up his dramatic victory in Rally Mexico with another commanding performance in Corsica, a rally known for its challenging asphalt roads and unforgiving corners. His pace in the opening stages clearly demonstrated his intent to build on the momentum gained from Mexico, where a last-gasp surge saw him snatch victory. The Tour de Course, often dubbed the 'Rally of 10,000 Corners', provides a stark contrast to the gravel and altitude of Mexico, demanding pinpoint accuracy and supreme confidence on high-speed tarmac. Meeke, driving his Citroen C3 WRC, seemed perfectly attuned to the demanding conditions, pushing hard from the very first kilometre. His ability to find an extra gear on the demanding Corsican roads left his rivals, especially championship leader Ogier, with little room for error. Ogier, ever the strategist, was playing a waiting game, conserving tyres and monitoring Meeke's incredible rhythm, knowing that any mistake on these narrow, tree-lined roads could be catastrophic. The battle between the two titans was shaping up to be a classic, with Meeke not just fighting for a win but for validation after a mixed start to the season. His victory in Mexico had silenced some critics, but a strong result here in the Tour de Course would solidify his position as a genuine title contender. The focus now shifts to the remaining stages, where the mental and physical demands would only intensify, testing the nerve of both the Dungannon driver and his relentless French pursuer.
label: T2

text: Kris Meeke edged out Sebastian Ogier to lead by 10.3 seconds after the first day of the World Rally Championship round at Corsica.
label: T3

text: Dungannon's Kris Meeke, driving a Citroen, secured victory in three of the four stages during the Tour de Corse. Sbastien Ogier remained close behind Meeke, who aims to follow up his dramatic Rally Mexico win with another triumph. Thierry Neuville of Hyundai sits in third place, trailing the leader by 25.8 seconds. Meeke asserted his dominance early in the season's first asphalt round, winning the opening stage and adding two more victories before day's end. Four-time world champion Ogier, in his M-Sport Ford, was fastest in SS3, reducing Meeke's lead to just over eight seconds. However, Meeke responded in the final stage, pushing his advantage beyond 10 seconds. Meeke, aged 37, expressed satisfaction, remarking, "It's been a good day." He acknowledged the constant pressure from "Seb," stating, "You always have to be wary of Seb, because he never gives up. But I'm comfortable with my pace, so let's see how we go on Saturday." Meanwhile, Meeke's Citroen teammate, Craig Breen from Waterford, holds an impressive fourth position, currently engaged in a close contest with Spanish competitor Dani Sordo.

text: Writing in the Sunday Times, the Plaid Cymru leader urged Wales to "speak with one voice". The UKIP leader and Welsh first minister will lock horns on Monday at an event in Cardiff. The UK is set to have a referendum by the end of 2017 on whether or not to remain a member of the European Union. Ms Wood said the bid for EU reform was "legitimate" but added any concerns were "far outweighed" by the benefits EU membership brings to Wales' agricultural sector, higher education institutions and transport infrastructure. She criticised Prime Minister David Cameron for allowing ministers to campaign for either side in the referendum, calling his decision "irresponsible and bizarre". And she said the issue would "alter the terms of the debate" in the lead up to National Assembly elections in Wales on 5 May.
label: T1

text: Writing in the Sunday Times , the Plaid Cymru leader urged Wales to " speak with one voice " . The UKIP leader and Welsh first minister will lock horns on the contentious issue of Wales's future within the United Kingdom and its relationship with the European Union post-Brexit. Ms Wood's appeal for unity underscores her party's concern that without a coherent and strong Welsh position, the nation's interests could be marginalized during negotiations with the UK Government and Brussels. She stressed the importance of protecting Welsh jobs, industries, and funding streams, advocating for a bespoke deal that reflects Wales's unique economic and social landscape. The UKIP leader, conversely, is expected to champion a swift and complete departure from the EU, arguing that such a move would unlock significant opportunities for Welsh prosperity and autonomy. This forthcoming debate highlights the deep political divisions across Wales regarding its future path, contrasting sharply with Ms Wood's call for a unified approach to ensure Wales's voice is heard effectively amidst the complexities of a changing UK.
label: T2

text: The EU is "too important to be discarded", Leanne Wood has said ahead of a head-to-head debate between Nigel Farage and Carwyn Jones on the issue.
label: T3

text: The leader of Plaid Cymru, writing in the Sunday Times, called for Wales to present a united front. A confrontation is anticipated between the UKIP leader and the Welsh First Minister during a Cardiff event on Monday. A national referendum concerning the UK's continued membership in the European Union is scheduled before the end of 2017. Ms. Wood acknowledged that calls for EU reform were valid, but emphasized that the advantages of EU membership for Wales' agriculture, higher education, and transport significantly surpassed any disadvantages. She condemned Prime Minister David Cameron's decision to permit ministers to campaign on either side of the referendum, labelling it "irresponsible and bizarre." Furthermore, she stated that this issue would fundamentally change the nature of the discussion leading up to the Welsh National Assembly elections on May 5th.
label: T4

text: It 's reported he had the idea at 2 pm and after a whirl of speculation , and a few changes of venue , tickets went on sale for Koko in Camden at 7 pm . Crowds waited hours in the cold before Kanye eventually took to the stage about 1.20am . The anticipation was palpable, a testament to the artist's magnetic pull, even amidst the late hour and biting chill. When the lights dimmed and the first notes rang out, a collective roar erupted from the packed Koko, transforming the long wait into a forgotten inconvenience. Kanye, known for his electrifying, often unpredictable, live shows, launched into a powerful set, blending tracks from his expansive discography with new material. The energy was electric, a raw connection between the artist and his dedicated fanbase. The night, however, held even more surprises for the Camden crowd. Mid-set, the atmosphere intensified as London's grime royalty emerged. First, the iconic Skepta exploded onto the stage, sending the venue into a frenzy with a blistering performance, solidifying the long-rumored collaboration. The crowd was already in raptures when JME joined his brother, delivering a high-octane display that further elevated the sky-high energy. The sight of these titans sharing the stage was pure magic, a cultural convergence. Adding to the international flavour, Vic Mensa, a close collaborator of Kanyes, also made a surprise appearance, showcasing his distinct flow. The mix of long-time fans and eager newcomers savoured every second of the historic, unconventional concert. It was a chaotic, brilliant night that cemented Kanye's reputation for pushing boundaries and delivering unforgettable experiences, leaving an indelible mark on London's music scene and the fervent crowd who braved the elements for a truly special performance.
label: T2

text: Kanye West has been joined on stage by an all-star line-up at a secret gig in London.
label: T3

text: The concept for the event reportedly emerged at 2 PM. Following intense speculation and several location changes, tickets for the Koko venue in Camden became available at 7 PM. Despite waiting for hours in the cold, the audience didn't see Kanye perform until approximately 1:20 AM. He was accompanied onstage by Skepta, JME, Novelist, Vic Mensa, Meridian Dan, Raekwon, and Cyhi. Radio 1's Clara Amfo, who attended, described the scene as "ridiculous," with "hordes of people outside," calling it "crazy." Access to the venue for fans began around 12:45 AM, though Kanye's performance didn't commence until over half an hour later. Grimmy expressed disappointment at missing the event, citing his need to "get up and do the radio [Radio 1 breakfast show]." Nevertheless, he admired its spontaneous nature, commenting, "I love that it was like, panic, it's exciting it's tonight." Clara informed Grimmy that Kanye "smashed it." She added that "He's like trolling the UK right now and I totally fell for it." Beyond performing classic hits such as "Jesus Walks" and "Clique," he also gave a sneak peek of his latest collaboration with Vic Mensa. Mistajam from 1Xtra was also in attendance, tweeting, "Tonight will go down in history." For more updates, follow @BBCNewsbeat on Twitter and Instagram, and Radio1Newsbeat on YouTube.

text: PwC's annual survey shows that just 37% think the economy will improve in 2015, down from 44% last year. Perhaps unsurprisingly, Russia's bosses have gone from the most confident to the least, due to problems caused by sanctions and the falling oil price. In the UK, concern had risen sharply about the availability of talent. The number of chief executives concerned about the skills gap rose from 64% last year to 84% this year. That is considerably higher than in Germany, France or Spain. This was partly put down to the high level of employment in the UK, which means that there is a smaller pool of workers to choose from, and partly due to concerns about the education system. On a global level, the biggest worries that chief executives have are geo-political uncertainties, over-regulation and cyber security. The report, which was launched at the World Economic Forum, in Davos, said that "concerns about cyber threats have shot up most compared to last year - and in light of the recent attacks on gaming and entertainment networks, the perceived risk will only increase". Dennis Nally, chairman of PwC said: "CEO confidence is down notably in oil-producing nations around the world as a result of plummeting crude oil prices. Russia CEOs, for example, were the most confident in last year's survey, but are the least confident this year. "Confidence has also slipped among CEOs in the Middle East, Venezuela, and Nigeria," he said. He also pointed out that there appeared to a shift in confidence from emerging market to western markets. Chief executives ranked the US as their most important market for growth over the next year, putting it ahead of China for the first time in the five years that the question has been asked. PwC interviewed more than 1,300 chief executives in 77 countries for the survey. It was carried in the final three months of 2014.
label: T1

text: PwC 's annual survey shows that just 37 % think the economy will improve in 2015 , down from 44 % last year . Perhaps unsurprisingly , Russia 's bosses have gone from the most confident to the least , due to problems caused by sanctions and the falling oil price . In the UK , concern had risen sharply about the availability of talent . The number of chief executives concerned about the availability of key skills had risen sharply. This growing talent crunch in the UK, as revealed by the PwC survey, is seen as a significant threat to growth and competitiveness. Many UK businesses report struggling to find and retain staff with essential digital and technical competencies, leading to increased investment in upskilling existing workforces and a focus on attracting international talent where possible. In contrast to the UK's talent focus, business leaders in Germany and France voiced different primary concerns. German CEOs, while relatively more optimistic than their French counterparts, were predominantly worried about global demand slowdowns and geopolitical instability impacting their export-heavy industries. The eurozone's tepid recovery also cast a shadow, with concerns over deflation and consumer spending remaining high. In France, chief executives were more preoccupied with domestic regulatory burdens and the need for structural reforms to stimulate economic activity. Confidence levels remained subdued across both nations, reflecting a cautious European outlook amidst ongoing economic uncertainties and the lingering effects of the debt crisis. Globally, the PwC survey of over 1,300 CEOs highlighted a universal shift towards caution. Beyond Russia's unique challenges stemming from sanctions and falling oil prices, and the UK's specific talent woes, the overall sentiment was one of strategic retrenchment. Only 37% of chief executives globally expected economic improvement, down from 44%. This marked decline underscores a pervasive sense of uncertainty across various regions, influenced by factors ranging from commodity price volatility to geopolitical tensions. CEOs indicated a greater focus on operational efficiency, cost control, and organic growth strategies, with less appetite for aggressive expansion. Investment in innovation, particularly digital technologies, emerged as a key priority to build resilience and secure competitive advantage in a volatile global market.
label: T2

text: Chief executives are less optimistic about the economy this year than last, a survey unveiled at the World Economic Forum suggests.
label: T3

text: According to PwC's yearly survey, only 37% of respondents anticipate economic improvement in 2015, a decrease from 44% in the previous year. Unsurprisingly, Russian executives, once the most optimistic, are now the least so, a shift attributed to sanctions and declining oil prices. In the United Kingdom, there has been a significant increase in apprehension regarding talent availability. The percentage of CEOs in the UK worried about skill shortages jumped from 64% last year to 84% this year, a rate significantly exceeding that in Germany, France, or Spain. This escalating concern is partly attributed to the UK's high employment rates, which reduce the available talent pool, and partly to worries about the quality of the education system. Globally, the primary concerns for chief executives include geopolitical instability, excessive regulation, and cyber security threats. The report, unveiled at the World Economic Forum in Davos, highlighted that apprehension concerning cyber threats has risen more than any other issue since last year, noting that recent attacks on gaming and entertainment networks are expected to further elevate this perceived risk. Dennis Nally, PwC's chairman, commented that CEO confidence has significantly declined in oil-producing countries globally, primarily due to collapsing crude oil prices. He cited Russian CEOs as a prime example, shifting from being the most confident in the prior year's survey to the least confident this year. Nally added that executives in the Middle East, Venezuela, and Nigeria have also experienced a drop in confidence. Furthermore, he observed a noticeable transfer of confidence from emerging markets towards Western economies. For the upcoming year, chief executives identified the United States as their top market for growth, surpassing China for the first time since this question was introduced five years ago. PwC conducted this survey by interviewing over 1,300 chief executives across 77 nations during the last quarter of 2014.
label: T4

text: The findings, to be discussed by the cabinet, revealed 17 "interim staff" were being paid more than 500 a day and two cost more than 800. Opposition Conservatives have criticised the spending as exorbitant. The Labour-led unitary council said the expertise was needed to oversee a restructuring programme designed to save money in the long-term. The council said many of the temporary staff were providing short-term expertise on a project which aimed to save 30m by changing the way the council delivered services. Conservative councillor Ian Bowyer said: "It seems to me at this moment in time Plymouth taxpayers are being asked to take a tremendous leap in the dark in the hope that we get a result at the end of the day. "It's far from clear what that result might be." The council said it was recruiting permanent staff for five of the posts.
label: T1

text: The findings , to be discussed by the cabinet , revealed 17 " interim staff " were being paid more than 500 a day and two cost more than 800 . Opposition Conservatives immediately slammed the ruling Labour administration at Plymouth City Council, with Councillor Ian Bowyer, leader of the Conservative group, describing the expenditure on temporary staff as an outrageous waste of taxpayer money. Bowyer expressed his dismay, stating, It is utterly indefensible that while vital frontline services face cuts and residents struggle, this Labour council allows millions to be siphoned off to external consultants earning exorbitant daily rates. This is not just poor financial management; it is a betrayal of trust. We have consistently called for greater transparency and accountability regarding council spending on agency staff. These eye-watering salaries highlight a deep-seated problem within the council's staffing strategy, pointing to an over-reliance on costly short-term solutions rather than investing in permanent expertise. The public deserves to know why these highly paid interim staff are deemed necessary and what value they provide, especially when permanent council employees face pay freezes. This clearly demonstrates the Labour group's inability to manage city finances responsibly, prioritising a costly, ad-hoc approach over sustainable planning for Plymouths future.

text: On Monday, Mrs May met the first and deputy first ministers on a one-day visit to Northern Ireland. She stressed that no-one wanted a return to the "borders of the past". Her meeting with Mr Kenny is understood to have focused on the impact of Brexit on British and Irish relations. Earlier in July, shortly after her appointment as the new prime minister, Mrs May spoke to Mr Kenny by telephone and agreed to build on the "strong relationship" between the UK and the Republic of Ireland.. Northern Ireland Secretary of State James Brokenshire described Mrs May's meeting with Arlene Foster and Martin McGuinness on Monday as "positive". He also said there was agreement about protecting the current border arrangements between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland. "I think that the prime minister had a really helpful exchange with the first minister and the deputy first minister and I think there is a strong will and strong commitment to not see the return to the borders of the past," he said. "Indeed that's a theme that underlined discussions that I previously had with the taoiseach on Friday." Mr Brokenshire added that there were "treaties and various other mechanisms" in place that underlined that there was a "different arrangement" between the United Kingdom and the Republic of Ireland. Deputy First Minister Martin McGuinness said he hoped there would be an "arrangement which will see the people of the north of Ireland continuing to see their future in Europe as part of an imaginative solution." The DUP MP Gavin Robinson said there were "two aspects" that had to be considered relating to the border. "So far, discussions have focussed on the movement of people, there will also need to be a discussion about the movement of goods, customs and whether or not there is a form of a single market or not, whether there is a disparity in tariffs or not and if that is the case, then how you control that," he said. "So whilst I see no difficulty in getting an arrangement that builds on the Common Travel Area and that allows you and I to move freely into the Republic of Ireland and similarly people from the Republic of Ireland can move freely into the United Kingdom, knowing that we have a uniform immigration policy, it may well be that further discussions will need to take place."
label: T1

text: Prime Minister Theresa May has held talks with Taoiseach (Irish Prime Minister) Enda Kenny at Downing Street.
label: T3

text: Prime Minister Mrs. May held discussions with Northern Ireland's First and Deputy First Ministers on Monday during a single-day visit to the region. She underscored the commitment to prevent a return to the "borders of the past." Her meeting with Taoiseach Kenny reportedly centered on Brexit's implications for British and Irish relations. Earlier in July, soon after becoming Prime Minister, Mrs. May had a phone conversation with Mr. Kenny, agreeing to strengthen the "strong relationship" between the UK and the Republic of Ireland. Northern Ireland Secretary of State James Brokenshire characterized Mrs. May's Monday meeting with Arlene Foster and Martin McGuinness as productive. He also stated there was consensus on safeguarding existing border arrangements between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland. Brokenshire remarked that the Prime Minister had a very constructive discussion with the First and Deputy First Ministers, expressing a strong resolve to avoid the re-establishment of "borders of the past." He noted this theme also underpinned his earlier talks with the Taoiseach last Friday. Mr. Brokenshire further stated that existing "treaties and various other mechanisms" affirm a "distinct arrangement" between the United Kingdom and the Republic of Ireland. Deputy First Minister Martin McGuinness expressed hope for a future arrangement that enables Northern Ireland residents to retain their European outlook as part of an innovative solution. DUP MP Gavin Robinson identified "two aspects" requiring consideration regarding the border situation. He explained that while talks have primarily addressed human mobility, future conversations must encompass trade, customs procedures, the potential for a single market, and any tariff differences, along with how such disparities would be managed. Robinson noted that while he foresaw no issues in establishing an arrangement based on the Common Travel Area, permitting free movement between the Republic of Ireland and the UK given their consistent immigration policies, he acknowledged that additional talks would likely be necessary.
label: T4

text: Zee Entertainment Enterprises said its entire catalogue of Bollywood films, recorded with Hindi dialogue, would be dubbed into Spanish. The channel, Zee Mundo, is the first attempt to market Indian movies in the Hispanic market. The firm plans to expand into Mexico, Argentina, Colombia, Peru and Chile. Bollywood movies - known for their extravagant action sequences, song and dance numbers, and vibrant costumes - have already enjoyed some success in non-Hindi speaking countries such as Nigeria and China, and some parts of Latin America. The company believes the Spanish-speaking market has cultural similarities to India, and that Bollywood content will appeal to audiences used to Spanish-language soap operas. In its promotional material, the company said it would offer the channel in high definition, with a complementary on-demand streaming service. "We are confident that Zee Mundo's programming will cross frontiers with storylines and themes that are relatable to the Hispanic audiences," said Amit Goenka, head of the company's international arm. Zee Entertainment Enterprises, one of India's largest media companies, claims to reach over one billion viewers globally.
label: T1

text: Zee Entertainment Enterprises said its entire catalogue of Bollywood films , recorded with Hindi dialogue , would be dubbed into Spanish . The channel , Zee Mundo , is the first attempt to market Indian movies in the Hispanic market . The move comes as Zee Entertainment Enterprises looks to tap into the fast-growing Spanish-speaking audience across the Americas, particularly in key markets like Mexico and the United States. While Bollywood films have a global fan base, language has often been a barrier for wider penetration in non-English or non-Hindi speaking regions. Dubbing the Hindi dialogue into Spanish aims to remove this barrier, making the vibrant storytelling, elaborate musical numbers, and compelling narratives more accessible to a new demographic. Zee Mundo will offer a mix of genres, from action and romance to drama, all tailored for the local sensibility, ensuring a diverse viewing experience for its Hispanic audience. This strategic expansion represents a significant investment by Zee Entertainment Enterprises to diversify its global reach and establish a strong foothold in a previously untapped market.

The company believes there are cultural commonalities between the Spanish-speaking market and India, anticipating that Bollywood content will appeal to viewers familiar with Spanish-language soap operas. text: Pte Sean Benton was found dead at the Surrey barracks with five gunshot wounds in June 1995, while on guard at a perimeter fence. Human rights group Liberty said the Attorney General had given his family consent to apply to the High Court. An earlier inquest recorded a verdict of suicide on the 20-year-old soldier. The coroner at a second inquest on Pte Cheryl James, who died at Deepcut in 1995 from a single gunshot wound, recorded a verdict of suicide earlier this month. The Cheryl James inquest heard from more than 100 witnesses. Delivering his verdict, Brian Barker QC launched a scathing attack on welfare standards at Deepcut and said there was overwhelming evidence of a sexualised atmosphere there. Liberty, on behalf of Pte Benton's twin brother Tony and his sister Tracy Lewis, lodged an application with the Attorney General in July 2015 requesting that the original inquest of July 1995 be quashed and a fresh one ordered. It said that since his death, many people had stated publicly and to his family that they believed Pte Benton, from Hastings, East Sussex had been the victim of physical and psychological bullying at the barracks. "We have been overwhelmed and disturbed by all the details of the shameful environment at Deepcut which have finally come to light through the Cheryl James inquest - it is terrible to think of Sean alone there," said Ms Lewis. "More than two decades after our brother died - and having lost both our parents in recent years - Tony and I are determined to find out what happened to Sean." Pte Benton was the first of four young recruits to die of gunshot wounds at Deepcut between 1995 and 2002. Liberty said the initial inquest a month after his death heard evidence from six people. Pte Benton's medical and mental health records were not obtained and no evidence was sought or given concerning his experiences at the barracks. Liberty lawyer Emma Norton said if Pte Benton's death had been properly and independently investigated in 1995, decades of pain and uncertainty for the family would have been avoided. Who were the Deepcut four?
label: T1

text: Pte Sean Benton was found dead at the Surrey barracks with five gunshot wounds in June 1995 , while on guard at a perimeter fence . Human rights group Liberty said the Attorney General had given his family consent to apply to the High Court . An earlier inquest recorded a verdict of suicide on the 20 - year - old soldier . The coroner at a second inquest on Pte Cheryl James , who died at Deepcut in 1995, concluded in 2016 that her death was not suicide but an 'unlawful killing', a landmark overturning of the original finding. Pte James was one of four young soldiers who died from gunshot wounds at the Princess Royal Barracks, Deepcut, in Surrey, between 1995 and 2002. The others were Private Geoff Gray, Private James Collinson, and Private Kevin Williams. All four deaths were initially ruled as suicides, leading to years of tenacious campaigning by their families, who consistently maintained that the circumstances surrounding their children's deaths were suspicious and that the original investigations were fundamentally flawed. The tragic sequence of Deepcut deaths became a national scandal, shining a harsh light on welfare provisions, alleged bullying, and the duty of care within the British Army. Families, often supported by organisations such as Liberty, fought tirelessly to have the original inquest verdicts quashed and new inquiries launched, believing that vital evidence had been overlooked or mishandled. The case of Pte Cheryl James, in particular, gained renewed traction when her parents, Des and Doreen James, secured a fresh inquest following years of arduous legal battles. This second inquest heard compelling evidence of a pervasive culture of fear, harassment, and even alleged sexual exploitation at the barracks, which her family powerfully argued contributed directly to her death. Similarly, the family of Pte Sean Benton, also found dead at the same Deepcut Barracks in Surrey, has long sought a new inquest into his death. His sister, Tracy Lewis, and other family members have consistently challenged the original suicide verdict, citing numerous inconsistencies in the evidence and a disturbing lack of proper investigation at the time. The recent consent granted by the Attorney General for Pte Benton's family to apply to the High Court for a fresh inquest underscores the profound and ongoing concerns about the integrity of the original inquiries into these tragic deaths. These landmark cases, driven by the extraordinary persistence and courage of the bereaved families and their dedicated legal teams, have had a profound and lasting impact on the understanding of military deaths and the standards of investigation within the armed forces. They have critically highlighted the urgent need for independent oversight and a transparent justice process when service personnel die in non-combat circumstances. The re-examination of these deeply troubling cases, particularly through the High Court and subsequent new inquests, represents a pivotal moment in the collective quest for truth and accountability, offering a glimmer of hope for long-awaited closure to families who have endured decades of anguish and unanswered questions regarding the deaths of their loved ones at Deepcut and similar military establishments.

text: The National Environment Research Council defended its decision to hold a public poll to suggest names, in which Boaty McBoatface got the most support. Professor Duncan Wingham said the row had "put a smile" on people's faces. But MPs asked if he would be made to "walk the plank" by ministers, who named it after Sir David Attenborough. Prof Wingham was giving evidence to the Commons Science and Technology Committee about the episode, which attracted huge public interest and divided opinion after Boaty McBoatface was passed over. He said that ministers' decision to name the vessel after the eminent zoologist and broadcaster - the option which came fourth in the poll - while allowing Boaty McBoatface to live on by naming a remotely operated sub-sea vehicle after it was an "eloquent compromise". Asked by Conservative MP Nicola Blackwood what the episode had done for public engagement in science, the academic said it had attracted "extraordinary attention" which could only be regarded as an "incredible success". "We could make the claim that we are probably the best-known research council in the world," he said. "We could make the claim that because of that there are hundreds of thousands of people, not only in the UK but around the world, who know about us and the science that we have done "In many ways we feel this has been an astonishingly great outcome for us. In addition, it has put a smile on everyone's face." Prof Wingham said NERC would do the same again in the future, although he said there were no plans for other boats at the moment.

To appease the public, NERC announced a compromise: a remotely operated underwater vehicle (ROV) on the RRS Sir David Attenborough would be named Boaty McBoatface. This solution allowed the beloved name to be incorporated into the scientific mission, ensuring its quirky legacy endured. The saga became a memorable case study in public engagement, forever linking Prof Wingham and the National Environment Research Council with Boaty McBoatface.

text: Profits at the technology giant were up 17% from the same period last year. "Our devices and services transformation is progressing," said boss Steve Ballmer in a statement. He added that Microsoft is launching a "wide range" of new products in the coming quarter. The report shed no light on who is to replace Mr Ballmer, who announced plans to retire within the next year. The company has released several new products this quarter, including an update to Windows 8, and recently bought the mobile phone unit of struggling Finnish giant Nokia. Shares rose 6% in after hours trading on the strong results. For the first time, Microsoft also announced sales of its tablet computer, Surface. It said revenues from Surface "grew to $400 million with sequential growth in revenue and units sold over the prior quarter". Last quarter, the company was forced to take an embarrassing write down of $900m after sluggish sales. The computer, well-liked by reviewers, marked Microsoft's first foray into hardware manufacturing. However consumers, many of whom expressed displeasure at Microsoft's update to its popular operating system Windows, did not bite. The company still did not provide sales figures of the device. Investors hoping for any information about who will replace Mr Ballmer in the new year were disappointed. Earlier today, on a conference call to discuss earnings, Ford boss Alan Mullaly declined to comment on rumours that he was being considered for the top job. Other contenders include Stephen Elop, the former head of Nokia, who resigned as boss after Microsoft announced it would purchase the Nokia's mobile phone unit for 5.4bn euros ($7.2bn; 4.6bn) in September. Mr Elop is now head of Devices and Services at Nokia, although he is expected to transfer to Microsoft - where he was once a top manager - once the deal is completed. Mr Ballmer has been at the helm of Microsoft since 2000, and has been at the company since 1980.

Our devices and services transformation is progressing , " said boss Steve Ballmer in a statement . He added that Microsoft is launching a " wide range " of new products in the coming quarter . The report shed no light on who is to replace Mr Ballmer , who announced plans to retire within the next year. The lack of clarity regarding Mr Ballmer's successor cast a shadow over an otherwise positive earnings report. Investors and analysts alike are keenly watching the search for the next chief executive, a decision that will profoundly shape Microsoft's future direction. Speculation has been rife, with names from both inside and outside the company being floated, including former Skype president Tony Bates and Ford CEO Alan Mulally, though Microsoft has remained tight-lipped about the process. The transition comes at a pivotal time for the Redmond-based software giant as it strives to redefine itself beyond its traditional Windows and Office strongholds. This "devices and services" push, championed by Steve Ballmer, represents a fundamental shift for Microsoft. It aims to integrate hardware and software more seamlessly, mirroring the successful strategies of competitors like Apple. However, the pivot has not been without its challenges. The reception to Windows 8, Microsoft's flagship operating system designed for touch-enabled devices, has been mixed since its launch, failing to significantly boost PC sales in a declining market. The acquisition of Nokia's devices and services division, a deal spearheaded by Mr Ballmer, is central to this strategy, promising Microsoft greater control over its smartphone ecosystem and a stronger competitive position in the mobile space. Analysts believe that the success of this transformation will largely depend on the new leadership's ability to execute on Ballmer's vision while also adapting to rapidly evolving consumer demands. The promised "wide range" of new products likely includes further iterations of the Surface tablet, potentially a smaller version, and new smartphones under the Nokia brand. The next generation Xbox console, though already launched, will also continue to be a key revenue driver. Despite the positive earnings, some analysts remain cautious, highlighting the intense competition in both the enterprise and consumer markets. The departing Mr Ballmer leaves behind a company in the midst of a massive strategic overhaul, and the next CEO will face the immense task of accelerating this transformation while simultaneously rekindling investor confidence and innovating at a pace previously unseen at Microsoft. The coming quarters will be critical in determining whether Microsoft can truly shed its legacy image and emerge as a dominant force in the mobile-first, cloud-first world.

text: The move follows a rise in the number of oil and gas operators using unmanned aerial systems (UAS) to conduct inspections and other offshore tasks. text: It is understood the Hammers will raise their offer for the player who began his career at the east London club . Defoe , 34 , has scored 11 goals in 21 appearances for the Premier League strugglers this season . His latest goals came on Monday as Sunderland twice fought from a goal deficit to draw 2-2 with Liverpool at the Stadium of Light. Defoe's two penalties highlighted his undiminished quality and vital importance to David Moyes' struggling side. Despite their precarious Premier League position, Sunderland are resolute in their stance that Defoe is not for sale. Moyes has repeatedly emphasized that losing their prolific scorer would severely jeopardise their survival hopes, particularly given how indispensable he has been to their attack. West Ham's pursuit, however, remains persistent. Manager Slaven Bilic is keen to secure a proven goalscorer, as the Hammers have suffered from inconsistent attacking performances and injuries this season. Bringing a player of Defoe's calibre and Premier League experience back to the London Stadium is seen as a key move to bolster their ambitions. The reported increased offer from the east London club is said to be around 6 million, but Sunderland are understood to value him considerably higher, closer to 10-12 million, reflecting his irreplaceable status. Defoe himself has maintained focus on his on-field commitments, embodying dedication to the Black Cats. His current priority is unequivocally keeping Sunderland in the top flight, a monumental task he has largely spearheaded. This transfer saga is expected to continue until the window closes, with West Ham anticipated to test Sunderland's resolve further, even as the Black Cats stand firm on their 'not for sale' position regarding their talisman.
label: T2

text: Sunderland have rejected West Ham's 6m bid for striker Jermain Defoe.
label: T3

text: Reports indicate West Ham intends to increase their bid for the striker, who began his career at the east London club. At 34, Defoe has been a key player for Premier League strugglers Sunderland this season, scoring 11 goals in 21 appearances. His latest contributions came on Monday, helping Sunderland twice recover from a deficit to draw 2-2 with in-form Liverpool, a result that leaves manager David Moyes's side in 18th place. Defoe's senior career started at West Ham before a 7 million move to rivals Tottenham in 2004, a deal that saw Bobby Zamora transfer the other way. He then joined Portsmouth for 7.5 million in January 2008, only to return to Spurs for 15 million the following year. A surprising move to Canadian team Toronto FC followed in 2014, until former Black Cats manager and ex-Spurs teammate Gus Poyet brought him to Sunderland in 2015. BBC Radio 5 live's chief football correspondent, Ian Dennis, suggests West Ham will indeed test Sunderland's resolve again. However, it's considered inconceivable for the Black Cats to sell Defoe given their vulnerable league position. David Moyes recently described Defoe as "priceless," stressing that his goal-scoring ability will determine their top-flight survival. The rarity of proven, high-calibre goalscorers is precisely why West Ham is pursuing the 34-year-old. While money often influences decisions, Defoe's value to Sunderland's Premier League campaign is truly unparalleled.
